sections.title: Overview
sections.content: Armenia is a landlocked country in the South Caucasus region, known for its ancient history, mountainous landscapes, and strong cultural identity.

sections.title: Capital City
sections.content: Yerevan is the capital and largest city of Armenia, serving as its political, cultural, and economic hub.

sections.title: Currency
sections.content: The official currency is the Armenian dram (AMD).

sections.title: Language
sections.content: The official language is Armenian, written in its unique alphabet created in the 5th century.

sections.title: Traditional Food
sections.content: Popular dishes include khorovats (barbecue), dolma (stuffed grape leaves), lavash (flatbread), and khash, a traditional soup.

sections.title: Geography
sections.content: Armenia is a mountainous country with the Lesser Caucasus range, fertile valleys, and Lake Sevan. Mount Ararat, though located in Turkey, is a national symbol visible from Yerevan.

sections.title: Culture
sections.content: Armenian culture emphasizes music, dance, literature, and religious traditions. The Armenian Apostolic Church plays a central role in national identity.

sections.title: Tourism
sections.content: Tourism highlights include ancient monasteries like Geghard and Tatev, the Temple of Garni, Lake Sevan, and the vibrant capital city of Yerevan.

sections.title: Fun Fact
sections.content: Chess is a national passion in Armenia, and the country has produced several world champion grandmasters.

history.event: The Kingdom of Urartu flourished around Lake Van and Mount Ararat, laying foundations of Armenian identity.
Armenia came under the influence of Alexander the Great after the fall of the Achaemenid Empire.
Under King Tigranes the Great, Armenia became a powerful empire stretching from the Mediterranean to the Caspian Sea.
Armenia became the first nation to adopt Christianity as a state religion under King Tiridates III.
The Armenian Kingdom was dissolved and incorporated into the Sassanian Empire.
Arab Caliphate conquered Armenia, introducing Islamic influence while Christianity remained dominant.
The Bagratid Kingdom of Armenia restored independence, with Ani as a flourishing capital known as the 'City of 1001 Churches'.
The fall of the Armenian Kingdom of Cilicia marked the end of medieval Armenian statehood.
Armenia became a contested land between the Ottoman and Persian Empires.
Eastern Armenia was annexed by the Russian Empire following the Treaty of Turkmenchay.
The Armenian Genocide occurred under the Ottoman Empire, resulting in the deaths of over a million Armenians.
The First Republic of Armenia was established after the collapse of the Russian Empire.
Armenia was incorporated into the Soviet Union as the Armenian SSR.
Armenia declared independence from the Soviet Union, becoming a sovereign state.
The Nagorno-Karabakh War broke out between Armenians and Azerbaijanis, leading to ongoing conflict.
The Velvet Revolution brought peaceful political change, leading to democratic reforms.
The Second Nagorno-Karabakh War resulted in territorial losses for Armenia.
